There were numerous cases where we

run into a problem where if you want to
have an overhang of the landscape, you
want to have even just a bit of a bit of
a more vertical kind of a landscape, you
couldn't necessarily do it because the
uh RVT uh is being projected from top

will also whatever material is on the
overhang will also be below that
overhang. So you cannot have different
layers in between them. Uh and also if
we just wanted to have larger worlds,
the RT would be fairly hard to scale to

pages but it would just incur much more

wanted to uh be wanted to deal with. Uh
second reason is simplicity. Simplicity

What can you write into the RVT? Um and

but what we did to curb that was we uh
did a different formatting of our
textures because at the time before uh
we went to the uh virtual texture
pipeline uh we used three textures per
layer and we used six texture samples
per per that layer. So each texture was
sampled two times. But the new texture
that we uh formatted was we call it NRD.
So normal tech normal info goes to the
RG of the texture. The roughness goes
into the blue channel and the
displacement goes into the A channel.
And with that we went down from three
textures to two textures per uh per
layer. Uh and another optimization that
we uh made to curb the six texture
samples is that we started baking out
our far textures. Uh the reason why we
had two samples per texture was that we
would have a near tiling for uh for the
layer and far far tiling for the layer.
So we had a lot of uh redundant info
being done per layer. So we would have a
baked texture as a far texture uh and
that would just be a single sample and
we went from six to two samples. So it
was uh it was immense saving on the SRV
count in general.
